question_details.query: How do long-term and temporary fishery closures compare in their effects on marine fish abundance?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from fishery closure studies, long-term and temporary fishery closures show markedly different effects on marine fish abundance. Long-term fishery closures demonstrated more positive outcomes, with two site comparison studies finding higher abundance of fish species in areas closed to groundfish fisheries for six to eight years compared to open areas (Action 2655). Additionally, one study found more young salmon returning to rivers in the five years after long-term closure of a commercial coastal fishery (Action 2655). In contrast, temporary fishery closures showed limited or no positive effects on fish abundance. One before-and-after, site comparison study in the Atlantic Ocean found no increase in the biomass of the spawning stock of cod following a temporary fishery closure compared to fished areas over nine years (Action 2664). Similarly, the same study found no change in cod catches following temporary fishery closure compared to fished areas (Action 2664). The evidence suggests that while long-term closures can lead to increased fish abundance and biomass in protected areas, temporary closures may not provide sufficient time for fish populations to recover and show measurable increases in abundance.
summary_statements: Based on evidence from fishery closure studies, long-term and temporary fishery closures show markedly different effects on marine fish abundance.
Long-term fishery closures demonstrated more positive outcomes for marine fish abundance.
Two site comparison studies found a higher abundance of fish species in areas closed to groundfish fisheries for six to eight years compared to open areas.
One study found more young salmon returning to rivers in the five years after the long-term closure of a commercial coastal fishery.
Temporary fishery closures showed limited or no positive effects on fish abundance.
One study in the Atlantic Ocean found no increase in the biomass of the spawning stock of cod following a temporary fishery closure compared to fished areas over nine years.
A study in the Atlantic Ocean found no change in cod catches following a temporary fishery closure when compared to fished areas.
The evidence suggests that long-term closures can lead to increased fish abundance and biomass in protected areas.
The evidence suggests that temporary closures may not provide sufficient time for fish populations to recover and show measurable increases in abundance.

question_details.query: What are the observed effects on fish abundance and diversity from prohibiting most or all fishing within Marine Protected Areas?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Marine Protected Areas that prohibit most or all fishing show significant positive effects on fish abundance and diversity based on extensive research evidence. Regarding fish abundance, 30 of 54 site comparison studies found that marine protected areas prohibiting all fishing for up to 25 years or more had higher abundances (density and/or biomass) of all fish, fishery targeted fish species, non-fishery targeted fish species, and all or most individual fish species/groups monitored compared to unprotected fished areas (Action ID: 2682). Five of six reviews across the world found that non-fished marine reserves with one to 27 years of protection had higher abundances of all fish and all fish and invertebrates combined compared to fished areas (Action ID: 2682). Two systematic reviews found that marine protected areas prohibiting all fishing had greater overall invertebrate abundance and biomass compared to fished areas (Action ID: 2224).

For fish diversity and species richness, 14 of 20 site comparison studies found that marine protected areas that had prohibited all fishing for between one to more than 25 years had higher fish species richness compared to fished areas (Action ID: 2682). However, six studies found similar fish species richness between one and 20 years after all fishing was banned in protected areas compared to fished areas, and one systematic review found no difference in species richness between unfished protected areas and fished areas (Action ID: 2682). One study found higher number of fish species in the no-fishing/no access zone of a multi-zoned marine protected area compared to partially fished zones and unprotected fished areas 10 to 15 years after implementation (Action ID: 2674).

The research also shows that fish in protected areas are larger than those in fished areas. Two global review studies and two systematic reviews found that prohibiting all fishing in marine protected areas for one to 27 years resulted in larger fish overall compared to fished areas (Action ID: 2682). Eight of 11 site comparison studies found that non-fished protected areas had larger fish overall and larger individuals of all or most fish species/groups monitored compared to fished areas, after one to 22 years (Action ID: 2682).

Community composition changes were also observed, with seven site comparison studies finding that protected areas where all fishing had been prohibited for between three and 16 years had different fish community composition compared to fished areas (Action ID: 2682).
summary_statements: Marine Protected Areas that prohibit most or all fishing show significant positive effects on fish abundance and diversity based on extensive research evidence.

Thirty of 54 site comparison studies found that marine protected areas prohibiting all fishing for up to 25 years or more had higher abundances of all fish, fishery targeted fish species, and non-fishery targeted fish species compared to unprotected fished areas.
Five of six reviews across the world found that non-fished marine reserves with one to 27 years of protection had higher abundances of all fish compared to fished areas.
Five of six reviews across the world found that non-fished marine reserves with one to 27 years of protection had higher abundances of all fish and invertebrates combined compared to fished areas.
Two systematic reviews found that marine protected areas prohibiting all fishing had greater overall invertebrate abundance and biomass compared to fished areas.

Fourteen of 20 site comparison studies found that marine protected areas that had prohibited all fishing for between one to more than 25 years had higher fish species richness compared to fished areas.
Six studies found similar fish species richness between one and 20 years after all fishing was banned in protected areas compared to fished areas.
One systematic review found no difference in species richness between unfished protected areas and fished areas.

One study found a higher number of fish species in the no-fishing/no access zone of a multi-zoned marine protected area compared to partially fished zones and unprotected fished areas 10 to 15 years after implementation.
Research shows that fish in protected areas are larger than fish in fished areas.
Two global review studies and two systematic reviews found that prohibiting all fishing in marine protected areas for one to 27 years resulted in larger fish overall compared to fished areas.
Eight of 11 site comparison studies found that non-fished protected areas had larger fish overall compared to fished areas, after one to 22 years.
Eight of 11 site comparison studies found that non-fished protected areas had larger individuals of all or most fish species/groups monitored compared to fished areas, after one to 22 years.
Changes in fish community composition were observed in protected areas.
Seven site comparison studies found that protected areas where all fishing had been prohibited for between three and 16 years had different fish community composition compared to fished areas.

question_details.query: Besides changing hook type in longline fisheries, what other gear modifications can reduce unwanted catches of sharks and rays?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Several gear modifications beyond hook type changes can reduce unwanted catches of sharks and rays:

**Longline Configuration Modifications**: Increasing the lead weight on mid-water longlines to increase the sinking rate and using nylon instead of wire hook attachments can reduce catches of unwanted sharks and rays compared to standard longlines (Action 2699).

**Electropositive Deterrents**: Fishing gear fitted with electropositive deterrent materials can catch fewer unwanted sharks and rays, and fewer undersized halibut, compared to standard fishing gear or gears with non-deterrent materials (Action 2696).

**Trawl Net Escape Systems**: Size-sorting escape grids (rigid or flexible) fitted to prawn/shrimp trawl nets reduce unwanted fish catches by allowing the escape of unwanted sharks and other fish species (Action 2721). Trawl nets fitted with both a size-sorting escape grid and a large supported escape opening reduce catches of unwanted sharks and rays compared to standard trawl nets (Action 2726). Bottom trawl nets fitted with square mesh escape panels and size-sorting grids reduce the unwanted catch of sharks and stingrays compared to standard unmodified trawl nets (Action 2727).

**Mesh Escape Panels/Windows**: Diamond mesh trawl nets with either a top square mesh escape panel or a large supported opening reduce unwanted shark catches compared to standard trawl nets, though this was not effective for rays and sawfish (Action 2716). Rigid escape windows fitted to trawl nets can reduce unwanted flatfish catches (Action 2719).

**Artificial Lighting**: LED lights fitted to fishing lines on shrimp trawl nets reduce catches of unwanted fish compared to conventional trawls (Action 2695).
summary_statements: Several gear modifications beyond hook type changes can reduce unwanted catches of sharks and rays.
Increasing the lead weight on mid-water longlines to increase the sinking rate can reduce catches of unwanted sharks and rays compared to standard longlines.
Using nylon instead of wire hook attachments can reduce catches of unwanted sharks and rays compared to standard longlines.

Fishing gear fitted with electropositive deterrent materials can catch fewer unwanted sharks and rays, and fewer undersized halibut, compared to standard fishing gear or gears with non-deterrent materials.
Size-sorting escape grids fitted to prawn or shrimp trawl nets reduce unwanted fish catches by allowing the escape of unwanted sharks and other fish species.
Trawl nets fitted with both a size-sorting escape grid and a large supported escape opening reduce catches of unwanted sharks and rays compared to standard trawl nets.
Bottom trawl nets fitted with square mesh escape panels and size-sorting grids reduce the unwanted catch of sharks and stingrays compared to standard unmodified trawl nets.
Diamond mesh trawl nets with either a top square mesh escape panel or a large supported opening reduce unwanted shark catches compared to standard trawl nets.
The use of a top square mesh escape panel or a large supported opening in diamond mesh trawl nets was not effective for reducing catches of rays and sawfish.
Rigid escape windows fitted to trawl nets can reduce unwanted flatfish catches.
LED lights fitted to fishing lines on shrimp trawl nets reduce catches of unwanted fish compared to conventional trawls.

question_details.query: What gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of cod and haddock in the North Sea?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Several gear modifications are available to reduce unwanted catch of cod and haddock in the North Sea. Separator trawls have been found effective, with one replicated, randomized study in the North Sea showing that a separator trawl separated unwanted cod from target fish species into the lower codend, where a larger mesh size allowed more unwanted smaller cod to escape capture (Action 2711). Topless or coverless trawls showed mixed results in North Sea studies, with one finding that topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger but not smaller haddock and larger Atlantic cod only in one of two cases compared to standard trawl types (Action 2712). Size-sorting escape grids (rigid or flexible) have proven effective, with eleven of 14 replicated studies in various locations including the North Sea finding that fitting size-sorting escape grids to fish trawl nets reduced catches of unwanted sizes of cod and other non-target fish, relative to the retained codend catch or compared to trawls without grids (Action 2720). Two of three replicated studies in the North Sea and Norwegian Sea found that size-sorting escape grids fitted to trawl nets improved the size-selection of haddock, but not cod, compared to standard nets without grids (Action 2720). Mesh escape panels/windows fitted to trawl nets showed effectiveness in North Sea studies, with fourteen of 19 replicated studies finding that square mesh escape panels/windows of varying designs fitted to diamond mesh trawl nets reduced unwanted catches of all fish species monitored compared to standard diamond mesh trawl nets (Action 2716). Square mesh codends instead of diamond mesh codends also proved beneficial, with three replicated, paired, controlled studies in the North Sea and other locations finding that trawl nets with an escape grid and a square mesh codend caught fewer unwanted cod and haddock compared to a diamond mesh codend with no grid (Action 2725).
summary_statements: Several gear modifications are available to reduce unwanted catch of cod and haddock in the North Sea.
Separator trawls have been found to be effective at reducing unwanted catch.
One study in the North Sea showed that a separator trawl separated unwanted cod from target fish species into the lower codend.
A larger mesh size in the lower codend of a separator trawl allowed more unwanted smaller cod to escape capture.
Topless or coverless trawls showed mixed results in North Sea studies for reducing unwanted catch.
One study found that topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger haddock but not smaller haddock.
The same study found that topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger Atlantic cod in only one of two cases compared to standard trawl types.
Size-sorting escape grids, which can be rigid or flexible, have proven effective at reducing unwanted catch.
Eleven of fourteen replicated studies found that fitting size-sorting escape grids to fish trawl nets reduced catches of unwanted sizes of cod and other non-target fish.
Two of three replicated studies in the North Sea and Norwegian Sea found that size-sorting escape grids fitted to trawl nets improved the size-selection of haddock.
These studies found that size-sorting escape grids did not improve the size-selection of cod, compared to standard nets without grids.
Mesh escape panels or windows fitted to trawl nets showed effectiveness in North Sea studies.
Fourteen of nineteen replicated studies found that square mesh escape panels or windows fitted to diamond mesh trawl nets reduced unwanted catches of all fish species monitored.
Using square mesh codends instead of diamond mesh codends has also proved beneficial.
Three replicated studies found that trawl nets with an escape grid and a square mesh codend caught fewer unwanted cod and haddock compared to a diamond mesh codend with no grid.

question_details.query: How do mesh escape panels, size-sorting grids, and large supported openings compare in their effectiveness at improving size-selectivity in trawl nets?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents, mesh escape panels, size-sorting grids, and large supported openings show different levels of effectiveness for improving size-selectivity in trawl nets:

**Mesh Escape Panels:** Studies show mixed results for size-selectivity improvement. Two of four studies found that modifying the position and/or size of mesh escape panels improved size-selectivity of haddock and whiting, while the other two studies found size-selectivity was similar for cod compared to standard trawls (Action 2717). When combined with size-sorting grids, one study found that size-selectivity of whiting was increased compared to standard nets (Action 2727).

**Size-Sorting Grids:** These devices demonstrate more consistent effectiveness for size-selectivity. Two of three studies found that size-sorting escape grids improved size-selection of haddock, but not saithe or cod, compared to standard nets without grids (Action 2720). Different designs and configurations of size-sorting grids show variable results - three of seven studies found better size-selectivity for unwanted redfish and Greenland halibut and commercial target hake compared to other designs, while three studies found effects varied between fish species, and one study found no improvement (Action 2728). When combined with square mesh codends, grids effectively reduced unwanted catches of whiting, plaice, cod, and haddock but not hake (Action 2725).

**Large Supported Openings:** The evidence shows these devices are primarily effective for reducing unwanted catch rather than improving size-selectivity. Six of seven studies found that large supported escape openings (including Fisheyes, Bigeyes and radial escape sections) reduced overall catches of unwanted fish, immature red snapper and total unwanted catch compared to standard nets, but no specific size-selectivity improvements were reported (Action 2723). When combined with grids, three of four studies found reduced catches of unwanted fish and sharks and rays (Action 2726).

**Combined Approaches:** The combination of mesh escape panels with size-sorting grids appears more effective than individual devices, with studies showing reduced unwanted catch and improved size-selectivity when both devices are used together (Action 2727).
summary_statements: Mesh escape panels, size-sorting grids, and large supported openings show different levels of effectiveness for improving size-selectivity in trawl nets.
Studies on mesh escape panels show mixed results for size-selectivity improvement.
Some studies found that modifying the position and/or size of mesh escape panels improved the size-selectivity of haddock and whiting.
Other studies found that size-selectivity for cod was similar when using mesh escape panels compared to standard trawls.
One study found that when mesh escape panels were combined with size-sorting grids, the size-selectivity of whiting was increased compared to standard nets.
Size-sorting grids demonstrate more consistent effectiveness for improving size-selectivity.
Some studies found that size-sorting escape grids improved size-selection of haddock, but not of saithe or cod, compared to standard nets without grids.
Different designs and configurations of size-sorting grids show variable results.
Some studies found certain designs of size-sorting grids provided better size-selectivity for unwanted redfish, Greenland halibut, and commercial target hake compared to other designs.
Several studies found that the effects of size-sorting grids on size-selectivity varied between different fish species.
At least one study found that size-sorting grids resulted in no improvement in size-selectivity.
When combined with square mesh codends, size-sorting grids effectively reduced unwanted catches of whiting, plaice, cod, and haddock.
The combination of size-sorting grids and square mesh codends did not effectively reduce unwanted catches of hake.
Evidence shows large supported openings are primarily effective for reducing unwanted catch rather than improving size-selectivity.

Studies found that large supported escape openings, including Fisheyes, Bigeyes and radial escape sections, reduced overall catches of unwanted fish and immature red snapper compared to standard nets.
No specific size-selectivity improvements were reported in studies of large supported escape openings.
When large supported openings were combined with grids, studies found reduced catches of unwanted fish, sharks, and rays.
The combination of mesh escape panels with size-sorting grids appears more effective than using the individual devices alone.
Studies have shown that using both mesh escape panels and size-sorting grids together can reduce unwanted catch and improve size-selectivity.

question_details.query: What are the comparative effects on fish abundance of prohibiting all static fishing gear versus prohibiting only line fishing?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the available evidence, there are limited direct comparative studies between prohibiting all static fishing gear versus prohibiting only line fishing. 

Prohibiting all static fishing gear: One study in the Coral Sea (Australia) found that areas closed to non-towed fishing gears had higher overall shark abundance when sampled with longlines but not gillnets compared to areas where commercial gillnets were permitted (action 2670). The same study found that shark length was greater for two of five species/groups, similar for two and dependent on sampling gear for one species in closed areas compared to areas where commercial gillnets were permitted.

Prohibiting only line fishing: One study in the Indian Ocean (South Africa) found that prohibiting offshore line fishing and all other boat-based fishing in a marine protected area zone resulted in higher abundances of four of four fish species over-exploited by line fishing, compared to two zones where boat-based line and spear fishing was permitted (action 2671). The same study found that four of four fish species over-exploited by line fishing were larger in the protected zone closed for two to seven years.

The evidence suggests both approaches can increase fish abundance, but the studies examined different fish groups (sharks for static gear prohibition, line-targeted species for line fishing prohibition) and different geographic regions, making direct comparison difficult based on available data.
summary_statements: Based on the available evidence, there are limited direct comparative studies between prohibiting all static fishing gear versus prohibiting only line fishing.

One study in the Coral Sea, Australia, found that areas closed to non-towed fishing gears had higher overall shark abundance when sampled with longlines but not gillnets compared to areas where commercial gillnets were permitted.

The same study in the Coral Sea found that shark length was greater for two of five species or groups, similar for two, and dependent on sampling gear for one species in closed areas compared to areas where commercial gillnets were permitted.

A study in the Indian Ocean, South Africa, found that prohibiting offshore line fishing and all other boat-based fishing in a marine protected area zone resulted in higher abundances of four of four fish species over-exploited by line fishing.
These higher abundances were found when compared to two zones where boat-based line and spear fishing was permitted.
The same study in the Indian Ocean found that four of four fish species over-exploited by line fishing were larger in the protected zone which had been closed for two to seven years.
The evidence suggests that both prohibiting all static fishing gear and prohibiting only line fishing can increase fish abundance.
The studies on these different prohibition approaches examined different fish groups, such as sharks for static gear prohibition and line-targeted species for line fishing prohibition.
The studies also examined different geographic regions, making direct comparison difficult based on available data.

question_details.query: What are the outcomes for fish populations when marine protected areas are managed with zonation systems that permit some fishing?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the evidence from action documents, marine protected areas with zonation systems that permit some fishing show variable outcomes for fish populations depending on the level of restrictions in different zones. In MPAs with zonation systems, fish abundance and biomass varied with the level of restriction between zones, with non-fished zones (no-entry and no-take) showing higher density, biomass, and abundance of fish compared to fished zones inside areas protected for 10 to 27 years, though effects varied between fish feeding groups, zone protection level, and reef region (Action 2674). Fish abundance and size were generally largest within no-take zones compared to partially fished zones within the same MPA system (Action 2674).

Regarding fish diversity, one study found a higher number of fish species in the no-fishing/no access zone of a multi-zoned marine protected area compared to two partially fished zones and unprotected fished areas 10 to 15 years after implementation (Action 2674). Fish size outcomes showed that controlling human activity in marine protected areas with zonation systems resulted in larger average lengths of steentjies and three seabream species compared to unprotected fished areas, with lengths being largest within a no-take zone than a partially fished zone (Action 2674). Additionally, larger sizes were found for four of four coral reef fish in zones where nearly all fishing is prohibited compared to adjacent zones with fewer fishing restrictions two to seven years after protection (Action 2674).

Fish movement patterns indicated that most individuals of reef fish species tagged and released inside protected areas were recaptured again at almost the same locations over four to nine years, mainly in zones where all or nearly all fishing was prohibited, indicating increased protection from fishing (Action 2674). However, one study found that restricting all fishing activity except for bait fishing in marine protected areas for seven years resulted in similar total fish biomass and lower total fish density compared to unprotected areas (Action 2681).
summary_statements: Marine protected areas with zonation systems that permit some fishing show variable outcomes for fish populations depending on the level of restrictions in different zones.
In marine protected areas with zonation systems, fish abundance and biomass varied with the level of restriction between zones.
Non-fished zones (no-entry and no-take) showed higher density, biomass, and abundance of fish compared to fished zones inside areas protected for 10 to 27 years.
The effects of zonation systems on fish populations varied between fish feeding groups, zone protection level, and reef region.
Fish abundance and size were generally largest within no-take zones compared to partially fished zones within the same marine protected area system.

One study found a higher number of fish species in the no-fishing/no access zone of a multi-zoned marine protected area compared to two partially fished zones and unprotected fished areas 10 to 15 years after implementation.
Controlling human activity in marine protected areas with zonation systems resulted in larger average lengths of steentjies and three seabream species compared to unprotected fished areas.
The average lengths of steentjies and three seabream species were largest within a no-take zone compared to a partially fished zone.

Larger sizes were found for four of four studied coral reef fish species in zones where nearly all fishing is prohibited compared to adjacent zones with fewer fishing restrictions two to seven years after protection.
Most individuals of reef fish species tagged and released inside protected areas were recaptured again at almost the same locations over four to nine years.
The recaptured reef fish were mainly found in zones where all or nearly all fishing was prohibited, indicating increased protection from fishing.

One study found that restricting all fishing activity except for bait fishing in marine protected areas for seven years resulted in similar total fish biomass and lower total fish density compared to unprotected areas.

question_details.query: How does the effectiveness of prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gear vary between the North Atlantic and other regions like the Mediterranean or Indian Ocean?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
The effectiveness of prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gear varies between regions, with studies from the North Atlantic, Mediterranean, and Indian Ocean showing different outcomes. In the North Atlantic Ocean, studies found mixed results with one study showing increased total fish biomass after 15 years in areas closed to bottom trawling, while another found no effect on abundance of bottom-dwelling fish species after 10 years (Action 2673). North Atlantic studies also showed no increases in haddock recruitment or survival seven years after bottom trawling closure (Action 2673).

In the Mediterranean Sea, effectiveness appeared more positive with studies showing higher biomass of adult red mullet after 14 years and increased recruitment of young red mullet after 14 years when areas were closed to bottom-towed fishing gears (Action 2673). The Mediterranean also showed increased adult red mullet sizes after closure (Action 2673). Additionally, Mediterranean studies of bottom trawling prohibitions showed different invertebrate community composition compared to trawled areas after 15-20 years, with mixed results on diversity depending on study duration (Action 2099).

In the Indian Ocean, results varied significantly between studies and species. One study found increased abundance of long-snouted seahorses but not short-snouted seahorses after one year of prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gears (Action 2673). Another study found that fish catch rates were higher in areas prohibiting seine nets for 3-6 years (Action 2673). Indian Ocean studies of complete commercial fishing bans showed larger overall fish sizes in marine reserves after five years compared to fished areas (Action 2667).

The evidence suggests that the effectiveness of mobile bottom fishing gear prohibitions may depend on regional factors, species studied, enforcement duration, and specific gear types prohibited, with Mediterranean studies generally showing more consistent positive outcomes than North Atlantic or Indian Ocean studies.
summary_statements: The effectiveness of prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gear varies between regions, with studies from the North Atlantic, Mediterranean, and Indian Ocean showing different outcomes.
In the North Atlantic Ocean, studies on the prohibition of bottom trawling found mixed results.
One study in the North Atlantic Ocean showed increased total fish biomass after 15 years in areas closed to bottom trawling.
Another North Atlantic study found no effect on the abundance of bottom-dwelling fish species after 10 years of a bottom trawling closure.
North Atlantic studies showed no increases in haddock recruitment or survival seven years after a bottom trawling closure.
In the Mediterranean Sea, the effectiveness of closing areas to bottom-towed fishing gears appeared more positive.
Studies in the Mediterranean Sea showed higher biomass of adult red mullet after 14 years in areas closed to bottom-towed fishing gears.
Mediterranean studies also showed increased recruitment of young red mullet after 14 years when areas were closed to bottom-towed fishing gears.
The closure of fishing areas in the Mediterranean also led to increased adult red mullet sizes.
Mediterranean studies of bottom trawling prohibitions showed a different invertebrate community composition compared to trawled areas after 15-20 years.
The effect of bottom trawling prohibitions on invertebrate diversity in the Mediterranean had mixed results depending on the study duration.
In the Indian Ocean, results from prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gears varied significantly between studies and species.
One Indian Ocean study found an increased abundance of long-snouted seahorses, but not short-snouted seahorses, after one year of prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gears.
Another study in the Indian Ocean found that fish catch rates were higher in areas that had prohibited seine nets for 3-6 years.
Indian Ocean studies of complete commercial fishing bans showed larger overall fish sizes in marine reserves after five years compared to fished areas.
Evidence suggests that the effectiveness of mobile bottom fishing gear prohibitions may depend on regional factors, species studied, enforcement duration, and specific gear types prohibited.
Studies in the Mediterranean generally show more consistent positive outcomes from prohibiting mobile bottom fishing gear than studies in the North Atlantic or Indian Ocean.

question_details.query: How do separator trawls and topless trawls compare in their effectiveness at reducing unwanted fish catch?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Separator trawls have been examined in two studies and show specific effectiveness in reducing unwanted catch. One replicated, randomized study in the North Sea found that a separator trawl separated unwanted cod from target fish species into the lower codend, where a larger mesh size allowed more unwanted smaller cod to escape capture (Action 2711). One replicated study in the Atlantic Ocean found that a separator trawl fitted with a square-mesh escape panel caught less of one of two unwanted fish species in a crustacean fishery (Action 2711). Topless (coverless) trawls have been examined in four studies with variable results. Two of four replicated, controlled studies in the North Sea, Gulf of Maine, and North Sea, Skagerrak and Baltic Sea found that using a topless trawl, in one case in combination with another non-conventional trawl type, reduced the catch of unwanted Atlantic cod and discards of commercial fish species compared to conventional trawl types (Action 2712). One study found that topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger but not smaller haddock and larger Atlantic cod only in one of two cases, compared to standard trawl types (Action 2712). The other study found that discarded catches of one of four commercial fish species were reduced in topless trawls (Action 2712).
summary_statements: Separator trawls have been examined in two studies and show specific effectiveness in reducing unwanted catch.
One replicated, randomized study in the North Sea found that a separator trawl separated unwanted cod from target fish species into the lower codend.
The lower codend of the separator trawl had a larger mesh size which allowed more unwanted smaller cod to escape capture.
One replicated study in the Atlantic Ocean found that a separator trawl fitted with a square-mesh escape panel caught less of one of two unwanted fish species in a crustacean fishery.
Topless (coverless) trawls have been examined in four studies with variable results.
Two of four replicated, controlled studies found that using a topless trawl reduced the catch of unwanted Atlantic cod compared to conventional trawl types.
Two of four replicated, controlled studies found that using a topless trawl reduced discards of commercial fish species compared to conventional trawl types.
In one case, a topless trawl was used in combination with another non-conventional trawl type.
The four replicated, controlled studies on topless trawls took place in the North Sea, Gulf of Maine, and North Sea, Skagerrak and Baltic Sea.
One study found that topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger haddock but not smaller haddock compared to standard trawl types.
One study found that topless trawls reduced unwanted catches of larger Atlantic cod in only one of two cases, compared to standard trawl types.
Another study found that discarded catches of one of four commercial fish species were reduced in topless trawls.

question_details.query: What are the documented effects of modifying fishing trap or pot configurations on marine fish?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Twenty-three studies examined the effects of modifying fishing trap or pot configuration on marine fish populations across various global locations including the Atlantic Ocean, Baltic Sea, Mediterranean Sea, Southern Ocean, Tasman Sea, Adriatic Sea, Bothnian Sea, Indian Ocean, Pacific Ocean, the Kattegat and the Barents Sea (action 2702). The documented effects include: survival impacts where one study found that survival of small herring escaped from a pontoon fish trap through a size-sorting grid was similar to trap-caught herring that did not pass through a grid (action 2702). Regarding reduction of unwanted catch, sixteen of 20 studies found that modifications to trap configuration, including using different trap types, increased mesh size and fitting escape devices, reduced unwanted catches of various fish species including brown trout, black sea bass, herring, bluethroat wrasse and leatherjacket, cod, protected rockfishes, whitefish, American eel and winter flounder, and sharks/rays compared to unmodified conventional traps (action 2702). However, three studies found that trap modification had no effect on unwanted catches of white croaker, non-commercial fish or undersized Atlantic cod, and one study found non-target haddock catches were increased (action 2702). For size-selectivity improvements, three of four studies found that traps or pots modified with square mesh escape windows or larger mesh sizes improved size-selectivity of Atlantic cod, black sea bass and most fish species compared to smaller mesh and standard gear, while one study found increasing mesh size of trap escape panels had no effect on size-selectivity of panga (action 2702). Additionally, trap modifications showed effects on marine mammals, with steel rods on lobster pots and metal frames on fishing pots reducing sea lion pup and seal entrapments (action 2822).
summary_statements: Twenty-three studies examined the effects of modifying fishing trap or pot configuration on marine fish populations across various global locations.

The studies on fishing trap modifications were conducted in locations including the Atlantic Ocean, Baltic Sea, Mediterranean Sea, Southern Ocean, Tasman Sea, Adriatic Sea, Bothnian Sea, Indian Ocean, Pacific Ocean, the Kattegat and the Barents Sea.
One study found that the survival of small herring that escaped from a pontoon fish trap through a size-sorting grid was similar to trap-caught herring that did not pass through a grid.
Sixteen of twenty studies found that modifications to trap configuration reduced unwanted catches of various fish species compared to unmodified conventional traps.
Modifications to trap configuration that reduced unwanted catches included using different trap types, increased mesh size, and fitting escape devices.

The fish species with reduced unwanted catches due to trap modifications include brown trout, black sea bass, herring, bluethroat wrasse and leatherjacket, cod, protected rockfishes, whitefish, American eel and winter flounder, and sharks/rays.
Three studies found that trap modification had no effect on unwanted catches of white croaker, non-commercial fish, or undersized Atlantic cod.
One study found that trap modifications increased non-target haddock catches.

Three of four studies found that traps or pots modified with square mesh escape windows or larger mesh sizes improved size-selectivity of Atlantic cod, black sea bass, and most fish species compared to smaller mesh and standard gear.
One study found that increasing the mesh size of trap escape panels had no effect on the size-selectivity of panga.
Trap modifications showed effects on marine mammals.
Using steel rods on lobster pots and metal frames on fishing pots reduced sea lion pup and seal entrapments.

question_details.query: What is the evidence for using electropositive deterrents on fishing gear to reduce unwanted catches of sharks and rays?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Nine studies examined the effect of attaching electropositive deterrents to fishing gear on marine fish populations, conducted across the Atlantic Ocean (USA, Canada, Bahamas), Gulf of Alaska (USA), South Pacific Ocean (Australia), Tasman Sea (Australia), and laboratory facilities (USA), plus one global systematic review (Action 2696). 

Regarding behavioral effects, three of four replicated studies found that electropositive deterrent materials attached near bait reduced feeding attempts and bait consumption of spiny dogfish, great hammerhead and draughtboard sharks compared to gear without deterrents, while one study found no reduction in bait consumption by bonnethead and young lemon sharks. Importantly, one study found that commercially valuable Pacific halibut behavior was unaffected by deterrent materials (Action 2696).

For bycatch reduction, two of four replicated, controlled studies in the Gulf of Alaska, Pacific Ocean and Atlantic Ocean found that fishing gear (longlines and traps) fitted with electropositive deterrents caught fewer unwanted spiny dogfish, longnose skate, sharks and rays, and fewer undersized halibut compared to standard fishing gear or gear with non-deterrent materials. However, the other two studies and a global systematic review found that electropositive deterrents resulted in similar catches of unwanted spiny dogfish, total shark catch, blue shark, and total sharks and rays compared to gear with no deterrents (Action 2696).
summary_statements: Nine studies examined the effect of attaching electropositive deterrents to fishing gear on marine fish populations.
The studies were conducted across the Atlantic Ocean, the Gulf of Alaska, the South Pacific Ocean, the Tasman Sea, and in laboratory facilities.
A global systematic review also examined the effect of electropositive deterrents on fishing gear.

Three of four replicated studies found that electropositive deterrent materials attached near bait reduced feeding attempts by spiny dogfish, great hammerhead, and draughtboard sharks compared to gear without deterrents.

Three of four replicated studies found that electropositive deterrent materials attached near bait reduced bait consumption by spiny dogfish, great hammerhead, and draughtboard sharks compared to gear without deterrents.
One study found no reduction in bait consumption by bonnethead and young lemon sharks when using electropositive deterrents.
One study found that the behavior of commercially valuable Pacific halibut was unaffected by deterrent materials.

Two of four replicated, controlled studies found that fishing gear fitted with electropositive deterrents caught fewer unwanted spiny dogfish, longnose skate, sharks, and rays compared to standard fishing gear.
The two studies also found that gear with electropositive deterrents caught fewer undersized halibut compared to standard fishing gear or gear with non-deterrent materials.
Two other studies found that electropositive deterrents resulted in similar catches of unwanted spiny dogfish, total shark catch, and blue shark compared to gear with no deterrents.

A global systematic review found that electropositive deterrents resulted in similar catches of unwanted spiny dogfish, total shark catch, blue shark, and total sharks and rays compared to gear with no deterrents.

question_details.query: In European waters, what does the evidence show about the effectiveness of using a square mesh codend instead of a diamond mesh codend for reducing unwanted catch?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In European waters, evidence from multiple studies shows that square mesh codends can be effective at reducing unwanted catch compared to diamond mesh codends, though results vary by species and location. Studies in the English Channel found that square mesh codends caught less non-commercial unwanted invertebrates in one of two areas, with similar amounts in the other area, compared to diamond mesh codends (Action ID: 2136). In the Bristol Channel, one study found that short-term survival of two of six fish species was higher after escaping through square mesh compared to diamond mesh codends (Action ID: 2714). Studies across European waters including the Aegean Sea, Mediterranean Sea, English Channel, and Bristol Channel found that square mesh codends reduced unwanted catches of all fish species monitored, young individuals of most commercially targeted fish, and total unwanted catch in some studies, though four studies found no reduction in catches of unwanted small rockfish and flatfish or total unwanted catch (Action ID: 2714). In the North Sea, studies found that trawl nets with escape grids and square mesh codends caught fewer unwanted whiting, plaice, cod, and haddock compared to diamond mesh codends (Action ID: 2725). Additionally, studies in the Adriatic Sea, Aegean Sea, English Channel, Mediterranean Sea, and the Kattegat and Skagerrak found that square mesh codends improved size selectivity for several species including European hake, horse mackerel, poor cod, greater forkbeard, and blue whiting, though five studies found no difference in size selectivity for other species like Atlantic mackerel and long rough dab (Action ID: 2714).
summary_statements: In European waters, evidence from multiple studies shows that square mesh codends can be effective at reducing unwanted catch compared to diamond mesh codends.
The effectiveness of square mesh codends at reducing unwanted catch varies by species and location.
Studies in the English Channel found that square mesh codends caught less non-commercial unwanted invertebrates in one of two areas compared to diamond mesh codends.
In one of two areas studied in the English Channel, square mesh codends caught similar amounts of non-commercial unwanted invertebrates compared to diamond mesh codends.
In the Bristol Channel, one study found that the short-term survival of two of six fish species was higher after escaping through square mesh compared to diamond mesh codends.
Studies across European waters found that square mesh codends reduced unwanted catches of all monitored fish species.
Studies across European waters found that square mesh codends reduced unwanted catches of young individuals of most commercially targeted fish.
Some studies in European waters found that square mesh codends reduced the total unwanted catch.
Four studies found no reduction in catches of unwanted small rockfish and flatfish when using square mesh codends.
Some studies found no reduction in the total unwanted catch when using square mesh codends.
In the North Sea, studies found that trawl nets with escape grids and square mesh codends caught fewer unwanted whiting, plaice, cod, and haddock compared to diamond mesh codends.

Studies in the Adriatic Sea, Aegean Sea, English Channel, Mediterranean Sea, and the Kattegat and Skagerrak found that square mesh codends improved size selectivity for several species including European hake, horse mackerel, poor cod, greater forkbeard, and blue whiting.
Five studies found no difference in size selectivity for other species like Atlantic mackerel and long rough dab when using square mesh codends.

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits of ceasing all fishing in a marine protected area on fish community composition and species richness?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
The documented benefits of ceasing all fishing in marine protected areas on fish community composition and species richness include the following evidence:

COMMUNITY COMPOSITION: Seven site comparison studies in the Mediterranean Sea, Indian Ocean, Philippine Sea and Atlantic Ocean found that protected areas where all fishing had been prohibited for between three and 16 years had a different fish community composition compared to fished areas (Action 2682). Additionally, three before-and-after studies in the Tasman Sea and South China Sea found that fish assemblage/species composition was different before and after prohibiting all commercial fishing (Action 2667).

SPECIES RICHNESS: Fourteen of 20 site comparison studies in the Indian Ocean, Mediterranean Sea, Philippine Sea, Tasman Sea, Atlantic Ocean, Caribbean Sea, Coral Sea and Pacific Ocean found that marine protected areas that had prohibited all fishing for between one to more than 25 years had higher fish species richness compared to fished areas (Action 2682). However, six studies found similar fish species richness between one and 20 years after all fishing was banned in protected areas compared to fished areas, and one systematic review in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans found no difference in species richness between unfished protected areas and fished areas (Action 2682). One replicated site comparison study in the Indian Ocean found that the effects of prohibiting all fishing on fish species richness/diversity after 15 years varied with the sampling method used (Action 2682).

CONTRASTING EVIDENCE: One site comparison study in the Caribbean Sea found that in marine protected areas closed to all fishing with limited exceptions for up to seven years, there was lower total fish species richness compared to unprotected areas (Action 2681). One before-and-after study in the South China Sea found that fish species richness decreased in the wider region five years after all commercial fishing was banned in two marine reserves (Action 2667).
summary_statements: Seven site comparison studies in the Mediterranean Sea, Indian Ocean, Philippine Sea and Atlantic Ocean found that protected areas where all fishing had been prohibited for between three and 16 years had a different fish community composition compared to fished areas.
Three before-and-after studies in the Tasman Sea and South China Sea found that fish assemblage/species composition was different before and after prohibiting all commercial fishing.

Fourteen of 20 site comparison studies found that marine protected areas that had prohibited all fishing for between one to more than 25 years had higher fish species richness compared to fished areas.
Six studies found similar fish species richness between one and 20 years after all fishing was banned in protected areas compared to fished areas.
One systematic review in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans found no difference in species richness between unfished protected areas and fished areas.
One replicated site comparison study in the Indian Ocean found that the effects of prohibiting all fishing on fish species richness/diversity after 15 years varied with the sampling method used.

One site comparison study in the Caribbean Sea found that in marine protected areas closed to all fishing with limited exceptions for up to seven years, there was lower total fish species richness compared to unprotected areas.
One before-and-after study in the South China Sea found that fish species richness decreased in the wider region five years after all commercial fishing was banned in two marine reserves.

question_details.query: How does using a square mesh codend compare to rotating a diamond mesh codend for improving size-selectivity in trawl nets?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Both square mesh codends and rotating diamond mesh codends can improve size-selectivity in trawl nets, but they show different effectiveness patterns. Action 2714 found that square mesh codends improved size selectivity for silver hake, horse mackerel, European hake, axillary seabream, poor cod, greater forkbeard, blue whiting, discarded fish and three of four commercially targeted fish compared to diamond mesh codends, while five studies found no difference in size selectivity for Atlantic mackerel, long rough dab, yellowtail scad and striped seapike, rockfish and flatfish, and three of four commercially important bottom fish species. Three studies found that the effect varied with fish body shape, with round-bodied fish showing improved selectivity but not flatfish. Action 2715 found that turning diamond mesh orientation by 90° resulted in better size selection of cod, red mullet and common pandora, and round-bodied fish species, but not of plaice, annular sea bream, and flatfish species compared to standard orientation diamond mesh. One study found that turned mesh did not improve size selectivity of cod, plaice and flounder. Action 2714 also found that square mesh codends reduced unwanted catches of all fish species monitored, young individuals of half or most commercially targeted fish, total unwanted catch, and discarded fish in deeper fishing areas compared to diamond mesh codends. Action 2714 reported that fish caught in square mesh codends had higher short-term survival rates for two of six fish species compared to diamond mesh codends.
summary_statements: Both square mesh codends and rotating diamond mesh codends can improve size-selectivity in trawl nets.
Square mesh codends and rotating diamond mesh codends show different effectiveness patterns for improving size-selectivity.
Square mesh codends improved size selectivity for silver hake, horse mackerel, and European hake compared to diamond mesh codends.
Square mesh codends improved size selectivity for axillary seabream, poor cod, and greater forkbeard compared to diamond mesh codends.
Square mesh codends improved size selectivity for blue whiting and discarded fish compared to diamond mesh codends.
Square mesh codends improved size selectivity for three of four commercially targeted fish compared to diamond mesh codends.
Some studies found no difference in size selectivity between square and diamond mesh codends for Atlantic mackerel and long rough dab.
Some studies found no difference in size selectivity between square and diamond mesh codends for yellowtail scad, striped seapike, rockfish, and flatfish.
Some studies found no difference in size selectivity between square and diamond mesh codends for three of four commercially important bottom fish species.
The effect of square mesh codends on selectivity varied with fish body shape.
With square mesh codends, round-bodied fish showed improved selectivity, but flatfish did not.
Turning diamond mesh orientation by 90° resulted in better size selection of cod, red mullet, and common pandora compared to standard orientation diamond mesh.
Turning diamond mesh orientation by 90° resulted in better size selection of round-bodied fish species compared to standard orientation diamond mesh.
Turning diamond mesh orientation by 90° did not result in better size selection of plaice, annular sea bream, and flatfish species compared to standard orientation diamond mesh.
One study found that turning the mesh did not improve size selectivity of cod, plaice, and flounder.
Square mesh codends reduced unwanted catches of all monitored fish species compared to diamond mesh codends.
Square mesh codends reduced unwanted catches of young individuals of half or most commercially targeted fish compared to diamond mesh codends.
Square mesh codends reduced the total unwanted catch compared to diamond mesh codends.
Square mesh codends reduced unwanted catches of discarded fish in deeper fishing areas compared to diamond mesh codends.
Fish caught in square mesh codends had higher short-term survival rates for two of six fish species compared to fish caught in diamond mesh codends.

question_details.query: How do the effects on fish community composition of prohibiting all commercial fishing compare between the Tasman Sea and the South Atlantic Ocean?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the action documents examined, there are notable differences in the effects of prohibiting all commercial fishing on fish community composition between the Tasman Sea and South Atlantic Ocean. In the Tasman Sea, two before-and-after studies found that fish assemblage/species composition was different before and after prohibiting all commercial fishing, with changes observed in an estuary after two years and in the wider region surrounding two marine reserves five years after their creation (Action 2667). Additionally, one before-and-after study in the Tasman Sea found that most fish species in an estuary in a marine reserve had lower abundance two years after it was closed to all commercial fishing than before (Action 2667). In contrast, the South Atlantic Ocean showed different results - one site comparison study found no change in species composition between a reserve closed to all commercial fishing for 40 years and unprotected fished areas (Action 2667). Furthermore, the same South Atlantic Ocean study found no difference in overall fish diversity between the protected area closed to all commercial fishing for 40 years compared to unprotected fished areas (Action 2667). Regarding fish abundance, the South Atlantic Ocean study found that there were higher abundances of one of four commercially targeted fish species in the protected area compared to unprotected fished areas (Action 2667). The key difference appears to be that Tasman Sea studies documented changes in community composition following fishing prohibition, while the South Atlantic Ocean study found no change in composition despite 40 years of protection.
summary_statements: There are notable differences in the effects of prohibiting all commercial fishing on fish community composition between the Tasman Sea and the South Atlantic Ocean.
In the Tasman Sea, two before-and-after studies found that fish assemblage and species composition was different before and after prohibiting all commercial fishing.
Changes in fish composition were observed in a Tasman Sea estuary after two years of prohibiting all commercial fishing.
Changes in fish composition were observed in the wider region surrounding two marine reserves in the Tasman Sea five years after the creation of the reserves.

One before-and-after study in the Tasman Sea found that most fish species in an estuary in a marine reserve had lower abundance two years after the estuary was closed to all commercial fishing than before.
One site comparison study in the South Atlantic Ocean found no change in species composition between a reserve closed to all commercial fishing for 40 years and unprotected fished areas.
A study in the South Atlantic Ocean found no difference in overall fish diversity between a protected area closed to all commercial fishing for 40 years compared to unprotected fished areas.
A study in the South Atlantic Ocean found that there were higher abundances of one of four commercially targeted fish species in a protected area compared to unprotected fished areas.
Studies in the Tasman Sea documented changes in community composition following fishing prohibition.
A study in the South Atlantic Ocean found no change in community composition despite 40 years of protection.

question_details.query: What does the evidence suggest about the timeframe over which prohibiting all fishing in a marine protected area leads to increased fish abundance?

summary_details.relevant_summary: The evidence suggests variable timeframes for fish abundance increases following fishing prohibitions in marine protected areas. Action 2682 found that marine protected areas prohibiting all fishing for 1 to 25 years or more showed higher fish abundances compared to fished areas, with 30 of 54 studies finding positive effects. Some studies found similar abundances between protected and fished areas between 1 and 20 years after implementation. Action 2681 found that restricting all fishing activity in marine protected areas for 1 to 8 years resulted in similar fish abundance and biomass compared to unprotected areas, with one study showing lower total fish density after 7 years. Action 2682 also found that effects varied between fish species and groups, with some studies showing that abundance effects depended on the age of the protected area. One review found that fish abundance in no-take marine reserves 1 to 25 years old was affected by duration of protection among other factors. Action 2674 showed that in zonation systems, fish abundance and biomass increased after 3-15 years compared to unprotected areas. Action 2667 found mixed results, with some areas showing higher abundances after 5 years and 40 years, while others showed no increase 2-13 years after closure.
summary_statements: Evidence suggests variable timeframes for fish abundance to increase following fishing prohibitions in marine protected areas.
Marine protected areas prohibiting all fishing for 1 to 25 years or more showed higher fish abundances compared to fished areas.
30 of 54 studies found positive effects on fish abundance from marine protected areas that prohibit all fishing.
Some studies found similar fish abundances between protected and fished areas between 1 and 20 years after implementation of the protected areas.
Restricting all fishing activity in marine protected areas for 1 to 8 years resulted in similar fish abundance and biomass compared to unprotected areas.
One study showed lower total fish density after a marine protected area was in place for 7 years.
The effects of fishing prohibitions on abundance varied between different fish species and groups.
Some studies showed that the effects on fish abundance depended on the age of the protected area.
One review found that fish abundance in no-take marine reserves that were 1 to 25 years old was affected by the duration of protection among other factors.
In zonation systems, fish abundance and biomass increased after 3-15 years compared to unprotected areas.
Studies on the effects of fishing closures on fish abundance have found mixed results.
Some protected areas showed higher fish abundances after 5 years and 40 years of being closed to fishing.
Other protected areas showed no increase in fish abundance 2 to 13 years after closure.

question_details.query: What is the evidence from global reviews on the effectiveness of catch share systems for managing fish stocks sustainably?

summary_details.relevant_summary: According to global reviews, catch share systems show evidence of effectiveness for sustainable fish stock management. Two worldwide systematic reviews examined the effects of introducing catch shares on marine fish populations (action 3812). One review found that fisheries or stocks managed under catch shares were more likely to meet management target levels for biomass sustainability than those that did not meet targets. However, another study found no difference in performance of biomass-based management targets between fisheries under catch shares, fleet-wide catch caps or fishing effort controls (action 3812). Regarding exploitation rates, two worldwide systematic reviews found that catch share fisheries had lower rates of over-exploitation compared to non-catch share fisheries, and a higher proportion of fisheries managed under catch shares either met or exceeded management target levels for rates of exploitation than those that did not meet targets (action 3812). One global systematic review comparing different management approaches found that catch share fisheries performed similarly to fleet-wide catch quotas in terms of reaching biomass-based management targets, and along with catch quota fisheries, fewer catch share stocks were over-exploited than those with effort controls (action 3811).
summary_statements: According to global reviews, catch share systems show evidence of effectiveness for sustainable fish stock management.
Two worldwide systematic reviews examined the effects of introducing catch shares on marine fish populations.
One review found that fisheries or stocks managed under catch shares were more likely to meet management target levels for biomass sustainability than fisheries or stocks that did not meet targets.
Another study found no difference in performance of biomass-based management targets between fisheries under catch shares, fleet-wide catch caps or fishing effort controls.
Two worldwide systematic reviews found that catch share fisheries had lower rates of over-exploitation compared to non-catch share fisheries.
A higher proportion of fisheries managed under catch shares either met or exceeded management target levels for rates of exploitation than fisheries that did not meet targets.

One global systematic review comparing different management approaches found that catch share fisheries performed similarly to fleet-wide catch quotas in terms of reaching biomass-based management targets.
Along with catch quota fisheries, fewer catch share stocks were over-exploited than stocks with effort controls.

question_details.query: What are the comparative effects of long-term versus temporary fishery closures on marine fish populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the available evidence, there are notable differences between the effects of long-term versus temporary fishery closures on marine fish populations.

**Temporary Fishery Closures (Action 2664):**
Five studies found limited positive effects of temporary fishery closures. One study in the Atlantic Ocean found no increase in cod spawning stock biomass, no change in cod survival, and no change in cod length composition over nine years compared to fished areas. However, tagged adult cod spent nearly a third of their time inside seasonally closed spawning areas, providing increased protection from bottom-dwelling fish gear during spawning periods. Studies showed mixed results on commercial catch, with some fish groups showing increased catch rates during temporary closures while others showed no change.

**Long-Term Fishery Closures (Action 2655):**
Five studies examining long-term closures showed more consistent positive effects. Studies found higher abundance of young salmon returning to rivers five years after closure, though effects varied by species. Fish in long-term closed areas showed reduced flight response distances, making them more vulnerable to capture. Long-term closures resulted in reduced overall fishing effort and varied annual catch rates. However, effects were still mixed, with some studies finding lower abundance of certain species like monkfish in closed areas.

**Complete Fishing Prohibitions (Actions 2667, 2681, 2682):**
The most comprehensive evidence comes from 79 studies on complete fishing prohibitions in marine protected areas. These studies found that areas prohibiting all fishing for one to 27 years showed higher fish abundances, larger fish sizes, higher species richness, and different community composition compared to fished areas. However, effects varied between species, with some showing similar abundances between protected and fished areas. The duration of protection influenced effectiveness, with longer protection periods generally showing stronger positive effects.

**Comparative Effectiveness:**
The evidence suggests that complete, long-term fishing prohibitions are more effective than temporary closures. While temporary closures provide some protection during critical periods like spawning, they show limited population-level benefits. Long-term closures and complete fishing prohibitions demonstrate more substantial and consistent positive effects on fish abundance, size, and community structure, though the magnitude of effects varies among species and depends on factors such as enforcement, habitat type, and the level of fishing pressure in adjacent areas.
summary_statements: There are notable differences between the effects of long-term versus temporary fishery closures on marine fish populations.
Five studies found limited positive effects of temporary fishery closures.
One study in the Atlantic Ocean found no increase in cod spawning stock biomass over nine years in temporarily closed areas compared to fished areas.
One study in the Atlantic Ocean found no change in cod survival over nine years in temporarily closed areas compared to fished areas.
One study in the Atlantic Ocean found no change in cod length composition over nine years in temporarily closed areas compared to fished areas.
Tagged adult cod spent nearly a third of their time inside seasonally closed spawning areas.
Seasonally closed spawning areas provided increased protection for adult cod from bottom-dwelling fish gear during spawning periods.
Studies on temporary fishery closures showed mixed results on commercial catch.
Some fish groups showed increased catch rates during temporary closures while other fish groups showed no change.
Five studies examining long-term fishery closures showed more consistent positive effects.
Studies found a higher abundance of young salmon returning to rivers five years after a long-term closure.
The effects of long-term fishery closures on salmon abundance varied by species.
Fish in long-term closed areas showed reduced flight response distances, making the fish more vulnerable to capture.
Long-term fishery closures resulted in reduced overall fishing effort.
Long-term fishery closures resulted in varied annual catch rates.
The effects of long-term fishery closures were mixed, with some studies finding lower abundance of certain species like monkfish in closed areas.
The most comprehensive evidence on fishery closures comes from 79 studies on complete fishing prohibitions in marine protected areas.
Areas prohibiting all fishing for one to 27 years showed higher fish abundances compared to fished areas.
Areas prohibiting all fishing for one to 27 years showed larger fish sizes compared to fished areas.
Areas prohibiting all fishing for one to 27 years showed higher species richness compared to fished areas.
Areas prohibiting all fishing for one to 27 years showed a different community composition compared to fished areas.
The effects of complete fishing prohibitions varied between species.
Some species showed similar abundances between protected areas and fished areas.
The duration of protection influenced the effectiveness of complete fishing prohibitions.
Longer protection periods generally showed stronger positive effects.
Evidence suggests that complete, long-term fishing prohibitions are more effective than temporary closures.
While temporary closures provide some protection during critical periods like spawning, temporary closures show limited population-level benefits.
Long-term closures and complete fishing prohibitions demonstrate more substantial and consistent positive effects on fish abundance, size, and community structure.
The magnitude of effects from long-term closures and complete prohibitions varies among species.
The magnitude of effects from long-term closures and complete prohibitions depends on factors such as enforcement, habitat type, and the level of fishing pressure in adjacent areas.

question_details.query: What are the observed effects of fitting deterrents, such as lights or electropositive materials, to fishing gear?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Electropositive deterrents attached to fishing gear showed mixed results for reducing unwanted catch. Two of four studies found that fishing gear (longlines and traps) fitted with electropositive deterrent materials caught fewer unwanted spiny dogfish, longnose skate, sharks and rays, and fewer undersized halibut, compared to standard fishing gear (Action 2696). However, two other studies and a global systematic review found that electropositive deterrents resulted in similar catches of unwanted spiny dogfish, sharks, blue shark and sharks and rays compared to gear with no deterrents (Action 2696). For behavioral effects, three of four studies found that electropositive materials reduced the frequency of feeding attempts and bait consumption of spiny dogfish, great hammerhead and draughtboard sharks, while one study found no reduction in bait consumption by bonnethead and young lemon sharks (Action 2696).

Artificial lights on fishing gear demonstrated more consistent positive effects. One study found that shrimp trawl nets with artificial lights caught fewer unwanted fish when fitted to the fishing line, but not when fitted to a size-sorting grid (Action 2695). For marine turtles, four controlled studies found that gillnets with LED lights, light sticks or UV lights caught fewer green turtles and loggerhead turtles than nets without lights (Action 3554). One study in the Adriatic Sea found that no loggerhead turtles were caught and died in gillnets with UV lights whereas some did in nets without lights (Action 3554). However, one study found mixed effects of increasing the number of light sticks on longlines on the chance of catching loggerhead and leatherback turtles (Action 3554).

Visual deterrents showed limited effectiveness, with one study finding that gillnets with floating shark shapes attached caught fewer green turtles than unmodified nets, and another study showing mixed effects of shark-shaped and spherical deterrents on loggerhead turtle behaviors (Action 3553).
summary_statements: Electropositive deterrents attached to fishing gear showed mixed results for reducing unwanted catch.

Fishing gear, such as longlines and traps, fitted with electropositive deterrent materials caught fewer unwanted spiny dogfish, longnose skate, sharks, rays, and undersized halibut compared to standard fishing gear.
Electropositive deterrents resulted in catches of unwanted spiny dogfish, sharks, and blue shark that were similar to gear with no deterrents.
Electropositive materials reduced the frequency of feeding attempts and bait consumption by spiny dogfish, great hammerhead, and draughtboard sharks.
Electropositive materials did not reduce bait consumption by bonnethead and young lemon sharks.
Artificial lights on fishing gear demonstrated more consistent positive effects.
Shrimp trawl nets with artificial lights caught fewer unwanted fish when the lights were fitted to the fishing line.
Shrimp trawl nets with artificial lights did not catch fewer unwanted fish when the lights were fitted to a size-sorting grid.
Gillnets with LED lights, light sticks, or UV lights caught fewer green turtles and loggerhead turtles than nets without lights.
In the Adriatic Sea, no loggerhead turtles were caught and died in gillnets equipped with UV lights.
In the Adriatic Sea, some loggerhead turtles were caught and died in nets without lights.
Increasing the number of light sticks on longlines had mixed effects on the chance of catching loggerhead and leatherback turtles.
Visual deterrents showed limited effectiveness.
Gillnets with floating shark shapes attached caught fewer green turtles than unmodified nets.
Shark-shaped and spherical deterrents had mixed effects on loggerhead turtle behaviors.

question_details.query: What are the most effective spatial management actions for protecting spawning fish and their habitats?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
Based on the evidence from action documents, several spatial management approaches have been evaluated for protecting spawning fish and their habitats:

Marine Protected Areas with complete fishing prohibitions show the most comprehensive benefits. Action 2682 found that ceasing or prohibiting all types of fishing in marine protected areas resulted in higher fish abundances, larger fish sizes, different community composition, and higher species richness/diversity across multiple studies. These areas provided protection for commercially important reef fish species and shark species for large proportions of time, effectively protecting them from fishing pressure.

Temporary and seasonal fishery closures provide targeted protection during critical spawning periods. Action 2938 found that spawning and nursery areas closed seasonally or permanently to fishing were used by tagged adult Atlantic cod for nearly a third of time during spawning, and by young school sharks for up to 80% of time. Action 2664 showed that tagged adult cod spent nearly a third of time inside seasonally closed cod spawning areas during implementation, providing increased protection from bottom-dwelling fish gears during spawning periods.

Long-term fishery closures demonstrate varied effectiveness. Action 2655 found that areas closed to groundfish fisheries for six to eight years showed higher abundance of some fish species, and areas closed to customary fishing for eight years resulted in fish having lower flight response distances, making them less wary of capture.

Periodic fishing restrictions offer a balanced approach. Action 2679 found that protected areas fished only for short periods over 18 months to six years had greater fish biomass than openly fished areas and similar biomass to areas permanently closed to fishing for six years.

Habitat protection measures supplement fishing restrictions. Action 2228 found that marine protected areas prohibiting dredging for approximately 2.5 years had different invertebrate and fish community composition and greater cover of habitat-forming species compared to unprotected dredged sites. Action 2654 showed that areas where fishing gears targeting bottom-dwelling species had been prohibited for 15 years had higher numbers of larger and older cod than openly fished areas.
summary_statements: Several spatial management approaches have been evaluated for protecting spawning fish and their habitats.
Marine Protected Areas with complete fishing prohibitions show the most comprehensive benefits.
Ceasing or prohibiting all types of fishing in marine protected areas resulted in higher fish abundances, larger fish sizes, different community composition, and higher species richness/diversity.
Marine protected areas with complete fishing prohibitions provided protection for commercially important reef fish species and shark species for large proportions of time.
Marine protected areas with complete fishing prohibitions effectively protected commercially important reef fish and shark species from fishing pressure.
Temporary and seasonal fishery closures provide targeted protection during critical spawning periods.
Spawning and nursery areas closed seasonally or permanently to fishing were used by tagged adult Atlantic cod for nearly a third of the time during spawning.
Spawning and nursery areas closed seasonally or permanently to fishing were used by young school sharks for up to 80% of the time.
Tagged adult cod spent nearly a third of their time inside seasonally closed cod spawning areas during the closure's implementation.
Seasonally closed cod spawning areas provided increased protection from bottom-dwelling fish gears during spawning periods.
Long-term fishery closures demonstrate varied effectiveness.
Areas closed to groundfish fisheries for six to eight years showed a higher abundance of some fish species.
Areas closed to customary fishing for eight years resulted in fish having lower flight response distances, making the fish less wary of capture.
Periodic fishing restrictions offer a balanced approach.
Protected areas fished only for short periods over 18 months to six years had greater fish biomass than openly fished areas.
Protected areas fished only for short periods had similar biomass to areas permanently closed to fishing for six years.
Habitat protection measures supplement fishing restrictions.
Marine protected areas prohibiting dredging for approximately 2.5 years had different invertebrate and fish community composition compared to unprotected dredged sites.
Marine protected areas prohibiting dredging for approximately 2.5 years had a greater cover of habitat-forming species compared to unprotected dredged sites.
Areas where fishing gears targeting bottom-dwelling species had been prohibited for 15 years had higher numbers of larger and older cod than openly fished areas.

question_details.query: How does the effectiveness of no-take marine protected areas on fish communities differ between the Mediterranean Sea and the Indian Ocean?
