summary_details.relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence from action documents, both Mediterranean Sea and Indian Ocean marine protected areas show positive effects on fish communities when all fishing is prohibited, though specific regional comparisons are limited. In the Mediterranean Sea, studies examining areas that prohibited all fishing for 3-16 years found different fish community composition compared to fished areas (Action 2682). Mediterranean no-take areas showed higher fish species richness and diversity in some cases, with 14 of 20 studies across multiple ocean regions including the Mediterranean finding higher fish species richness in protected areas compared to fished areas after 1-25+ years of protection (Action 2682). Fish abundance studies showed that Mediterranean protected areas had higher abundances of targeted and non-targeted fish species, with effects varying between individual species groups based on their commercial status and position in the food chain (Action 2682). Fish sizes were also larger in Mediterranean no-take areas, with 8 of 11 studies across multiple regions including the Mediterranean finding larger fish in protected areas after 1-22 years compared to fished areas (Action 2682). One Mediterranean study found greater reproductive success, with more eggs of four commercially targeted fish species in a 3-year-old reserve compared to fished areas (Action 2682). In the Indian Ocean, 15 studies examined the effects of prohibiting all fishing, with similar positive patterns observed (Action 2682). Indian Ocean protected areas showed different fish community composition compared to fished areas after 3-16 years of protection (Action 2682). Fish species richness and diversity were higher in Indian Ocean no-take areas in the majority of studies, following the same pattern as Mediterranean areas (Action 2682). Fish abundance was higher in Indian Ocean protected areas, with 30 of 54 studies across all regions including the Indian Ocean finding higher fish abundances in no-take areas after up to 25+ years of protection (Action 2682). Fish grazing rates were higher in Indian Ocean protected areas compared to fished areas (Action 2682). The documents indicate that while both regions show positive responses to no-take protection, the specific magnitude and timing of effects may vary based on local conditions, enforcement, and the particular fish species present.
summary_statements: Both Mediterranean Sea and Indian Ocean marine protected areas show positive effects on fish communities when all fishing is prohibited.
Specific regional comparisons of the effects of marine protected areas on fish communities between the Mediterranean Sea and the Indian Ocean are limited.
In the Mediterranean Sea, studies examining areas that prohibited all fishing for 3-16 years found a different fish community composition compared to fished areas.
Mediterranean no-take areas showed higher fish species richness and diversity in some cases.
14 of 20 studies across multiple ocean regions, including the Mediterranean, found higher fish species richness in protected areas compared to fished areas after 1-25+ years of protection.
Fish abundance studies showed that Mediterranean protected areas had higher abundances of targeted and non-targeted fish species.
In Mediterranean protected areas, the effects on fish abundance varied between individual species groups based on the species' commercial status and position in the food chain.
Fish sizes were larger in Mediterranean no-take areas.
8 of 11 studies across multiple regions, including the Mediterranean, found larger fish in protected areas after 1-22 years compared to fished areas.
One Mediterranean study found greater reproductive success, with more eggs of four commercially targeted fish species in a 3-year-old reserve compared to fished areas.
In the Indian Ocean, 15 studies that examined the effects of prohibiting all fishing observed similar positive patterns.
Indian Ocean protected areas showed a different fish community composition compared to fished areas after 3-16 years of protection.
Fish species richness and diversity were higher in Indian Ocean no-take areas in the majority of studies, following the same pattern as Mediterranean areas.
Fish abundance was higher in Indian Ocean protected areas.
30 of 54 studies across all regions, including the Indian Ocean, found higher fish abundances in no-take areas after up to 25+ years of protection.
Fish grazing rates were higher in Indian Ocean protected areas compared to fished areas.
Both the Mediterranean Sea and Indian Ocean regions show positive responses to no-take protection.
The specific magnitude and timing of the effects of no-take protection may vary based on local conditions, enforcement, and the particular fish species present.
